awd_titl_txt: Constraining the Nature and Formation Age of the Shyok Suture Zone in Ladakh, NE India
awd_abstract_narration:
The spectacular height and length of the Himalayan Mountain Belt has inspired generations of people across the world.  The mountain chain was formed during the collision of the Indian and Eurasian continents approximately 40-50 million years ago.  Before this collision occurred, an ocean called the Neotethys separated the two continents and the timing of its disappearance remains an open question. This project will better constrain the timing of the collision between the two continents by age dating and paleomagnetic measurements in the Kohistan-Ladakh region of northern India.  A better constraint on the timing of the collision and disappearance of the Neotethys ocean is essential not only for our understanding of the Himalayas, but also for addressing other big questions such as the how tectonic plates reorganize during major collisional events and the influence of tectonic forces on global climate.

The principal goals of this project are to better constrain the nature and age of the Shyok suture zone, and to test alternative models for the Kohistan-Ladakh-Eurasia collision. If the Shyok suture is younger than the Indus suture, then the Shyok-Tsangpo suture zone, not the Indus-Tsangpo suture zone, records the final collision of India and Asia, and two subduction systems were present in the Neotethys ocean until approximately 50 Ma.  We will conduct a detailed study combining field geologic mapping, petrology/geochemistry, U-Pb zircon geochronology, and paleomagnetic measurements. This work will constrain the currently unknown age and provenance of multiple sedimentary sequences in the suture zone as well as provide new information on the geochemical characteristics and ages of plutonic rocks within the suture and in neighboring terranes. Additionally, the proposed paleomagnetic work will determine the unknown paleolatitudes of both the Kohistan-Ladakh arc and Eurasian margins during the crucial time of the India-Eurasia collision and thus allow us to evaluate the different collision scenarios. The work related to this project constitutes a comprehensive and multifaceted documentation of a pivotal yet unconstrained suture zone in the Himalaya and offers the opportunity to capitalize on the recently increased access to crucial exposures in Ladakh, India.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project focused on the nature of the Shyok Suture zone in NW India. The formation age of the Shyok suture zone was poorly constrained, but of outsized importance to constrain the India-Eurasia tectonic evolution. The Shyok suture zone separates the so-called Kohistan-Ladakh arc (KLA) from Eurasia in the north, while the KLA is separated from India by the Indus suture zone in the south. The KLA was an intra-oceanic island arc forming in the equatorial area of the Neo-Tethyan ocean in the Late Jurassic/Early Cretaceous. Two evolutionary models have been proposed for the KLA collision with Eurasia and India: 1) the ‘standard’ model assumed the KLA collided with Eurasia in the Late Cretaceous and India collided with the KLA/Eurasia block in the Paleogene; 2) alternatively, it has been proposed that the formation of the Shyok suture postdates the Indus suture and the KLA collided first with India and subsequently the KLA/India collided with Eurasia in the middle Eocene. As the Indus suture is a well dated suture in the Himalaya, its formation age is often equated with the onset of the India-Eurasia collision. However, this model assumes all sutures North of the Indus are older and predate the India KLA collision

 

In this project, we finalized a geological map of the Shyok suture in NW India, which the PI has been working on for ~15 years, stretching from the India/Pakistan line of control (LOC) to the India/China LOC covering an area of ~15,000 km². The map details the main building blocks and structure of the Shyok suture zone. We conducted detailed paleomagnetic measurements to constrain the paleo position of the KLA and Eurasia in the Late Cretaceous. We find that these two continental fragments were separated by ~1000 km, conflicting with the presumed Late Cretaceous collision time postulated by the ‘standard’ model. Structural mapping combined with U-Pb zircon ages clearly indicates that instead, the Eurasian margin underwent significant extension and rifting in the Late Cretaceous, and we can constrain final suturing along the Shyok to <52 Ma, postdating the onset of suturing along the Indus suture. Our results clearly support a two-stage collision model for the western Himalaya in the Paleocene/Eocene.

 


Last Modified: 06/05/2024
Modified by: Oliver Jagoutz
